#Text=AN OLD HOUSE AND ITS BACHELOR
#Text=When the knell of my thirtieth birthday sounded , I suddenly realised , with a desolate feeling at the heart , that I was alone in the world .
#Text=It was true I had many and good friends , and I was blessed with interests and occupations which I had often declared sufficient to satisfy any not too exacting human being .
#Text=Moreover , a small but sufficient competency was mine , allowing me reasonable comforts , and the luxuries of a small but choice library , and a small but choice garden .
#Text=These heavenly blessings had seemed mere than enough for nearly five years , during which the good sister and I had kept house together , leading a life of tranquil happy days .
#Text=Friends and books and flowers !
#Text=It was , we said , a good world , and I , simpleton , -- pretty and dainty as Margaret was , -- deemed it would go on forever .
#Text=But , alas !
#Text=one day came a Faust into our garden , -- a good Faust , with no friend Mephistopheles , -- and took Margaret from me .
#Text=It is but a month since they were married , and the rice still lingers in the crevices of the pathway down to the quaint old iron-work gate .
#Text=Yes ! they have gone off to spend their honeymoon , and Margaret has written to me twice to say how happy they are together in the Hesperides .
#Text=Dear happiness ! Selfish , indeed , were he who would envy you one petal of that wonderful rose -- Rosa Mundi --
#Text=God has given you to gather .
#Text=But , all the same , the reader will admit that it must be lonely for me , and not another sister left to take pity on me , all somewhere happily settled down in the Fortunate Isles .
#Text=Poor lonely old house ! do you , too , miss the light step of your mistress ?
#Text=No longer shall her little silken figure flit up and down your quiet staircases , no more deck out your silent rooms with flowers , humming the while some happy little song .

#Text=The little piano is dumb night after night , its candles unlighted , and there is no one to play Chopin to us now as the day dies , and the shadows stoop out of their corners to listen in vain .
#Text=Old house , old house ! We are alone , quite alone , -- there is no mistake about that , -- and the soul has gone out of both of us .
#Text=And as for the garden , there is no company there ; that is loneliest of all .
#Text=The very sunlight looks desolation , falling through the thick-blossoming apple-trees as through the chinks and crevices of deserted Egyptian cities .
#Text=While as for the books -- well , never talk to me again about the companionship of books !

#Text=For just when one needs them most of all they seem suddenly to have grown dull and unsympathetic , not a word of comfort , not a charm anywhere in them to make us forget the slow-moving hours ; whereas , when Margaret was here -- but it is of no use to say any more ! Everything was quite different when Margaret was here : that is enough .
#Text=Margaret has gone away to the Fortunate Isles .
#Text=Of course she 'll come to see us now and again ; but it wo n't be the same thing .
#Text=Yes !
#Text=old echoing silent House of Joy that is Gone , we are quite alone .
#Text=Now , what is to be done ?
#Text=CHAPTER II
#Text=IN WHICH I DECIDE TO GO ON PILGRIMAGE

#Text=Though I have this bad habit of soliloquising , and indeed am absurd enough to attempt conversation with a house , yet the reader must realise from the beginning that I am still quite a young man .
#Text=I talked a little just now as though I were an octogenarian .
#Text=Actually , as I said , I am but just gone thirty , and I may reasonably regard life , as the saying is , all before me .
#Text=I was a little down-hearted when I wrote yesterday .
#Text=Besides , I wrote at the end of the afternoon , a melancholy time .
#Text=The morning is the time to write .
#Text=We are all -- that is , those of us who sleep well -- optimists in the morning .
#Text=And the world is sad enough without our writing books to make it sadder .
#Text=The rest of this book , I promise you , shall be written of a morning .
#Text=This book !
#Text=oh , yes , I forgot ! --
#Text=I am going to write a book .
#Text=A book about what ?
#Text=Well , that must be as God wills .
#Text=But listen !

#Text=As I lay in bed this morning between sleeping and waking , an idea came riding on a sunbeam into my room , -- a mad , whimsical idea , but one that suits my mood ; and put briefly , it is this : how is it that I , a not unpresentable young man , a man not without accomplishments or experience , should have gone all these years without finding that
#Text=" Not impossible she Who shall command my heart and me , " --
#Text=without meeting at some turning of the way the mystical Golden Girl , -- without , in short , finding a wife ?
#Text=" Then , " suggested the idea , with a blush for its own absurdity , " why not go on pilgrimage and seek her ?

#Text= By Heaven , I will take stick and knapsack and walk right away from my own front door , right away where the road leads , and see what happens .
